lexUnit.name: sandal.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a light shoe with an openwork upper or straps attaching the sole to the foot.

sentence.text: ` Walking in sandals on the lanes of south-west France . "
She came into the cobbled yard in front of the coach house walking carefully in her high-heeled sandals on the uneven ground .
She wore leather sandals with straps that came halfway up her calves .
She touched her eyelids lightly with gleaming gold shadow and her lips with soft red flecked with gold and put on her evening sandals with the gilt straps .
Aristotle ( 384-322 BC ) had created his philosophy while ambling in his sandals along the olive groves of the Lyceum in Athens and so his philosophy was dubbed ` Peripatetic " .
` I was the only kid in sandals in the whole neighbourhood . "
His gaze blatantly appraised her , from her bare toes in the soft white sandals to the smoothly groomed crown of her head .
On the porch outside the front door , I kicked off my sandals and pushed them to one side where they joined an already substantial pile of varying styles and sizes .
Kicking off our sandals we walked barefoot into the air-conditioned cool of the big room .
Taking off his topee , he wiped his head , looking almost comical in his shorts and sandals , but obviously all the Polynesians knew and liked him .
Once the machine was hissing and the aroma of coffee was spreading through the flat Rain tossed her bag on the couch , kicked off her sandals and opened the doors to the garden .
She brushed her hair and left it long and gleaming , slipped into dainty sandals and went downstairs .
She wears sandals a good deal , and bare feet .
Tavalouze said nothing but strode ahead of Lucien , his worn sandals slapping loudly against his feet and the marble flags of the corridor .
She slipped on some flat sandals , and made her way downstairs to the sound of voices .
